items.summary:
Key Points:
- Texas Farm Bureau President Russell Boening expressed support for the "Farm Bill 2.0" introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives by Committee on Agriculture Chairman Glenn "GT" Thompson.
- Boening called on all members of the House Committee on Agriculture to vote yes to move the bill out of committee, and for congressional leaders to support the legislation when it reaches the House floor.

items.title: Minnesota Farm Bureau Hosts Third Annual Urban Ag Conference
items.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. – The Minnesota Farm Bureau Federation (MFBF) hosted its third annual Urban Ag Conference on February 14 at St. Paul College, bringing together urban farmers, professionals and community members for a day of connection, collaboration and learning. The conference has become a place for urban farmers to come together and engage in sharing […] The post Minnesota Farm Bureau Hosts Third Annual Urban Ag Conference appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Minnesota Farm Bureau Federation (MFBF) hosted its third annual Urban Ag Conference on February 14, 2026 at St. Paul College. The conference brought together over 30,000 urban farmers, professionals, and community members for a day of connection, collaboration, and learning. 

Key highlights:
- The conference featured peer networking sessions and breakout learning sessions on topics like business planning, grassroots advocacy, soil health, land access, and produce storage.
- As the conference continues to grow, MFBF looks forward to supporting broader connections between urban and rural agriculture to strengthen Minnesota's agricultural community.
- MFBF is a advocacy organization representing over 30,000 members and 78 county/regional Farm Bureaus in Minnesota.
- The second annual Urban Ag Conference was held on February 22, 2025 at St. Paul College.
- MFBF will host its 2025 Annual Meeting on November 20-22 in Minneapolis, featuring educational sessions, organizational updates, networking, and recognition of agricultural leaders.
- The FFA Winter Leadership Summit on December 15, 2025 in St. Cloud drew nearly 250 FFA members for contests and workshops.
- The "Young & Emerging Farmer Workshop" on January 25, 2026 in Mankato provided tips for those starting their farming careers.

items.title: Montana Farm Bureau to Hold Comprehensive Campaign Seminar End of February
items.description: BOZEMAN, Mont. ‚Äî Running for office can be exciting, but it can also be daunting to know where to start and what strategies are needed to win. The Montana Farm Bureau Federation (MFBF) is hosting an interactive seminar February 26-27, 2026, at the Montana Farm Bureau Center in Bozeman. The American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF) […] The post Montana Farm Bureau to Hold Comprehensive Campaign Seminar End of February appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The seminar is developed by the American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF) with input from political consultants and staff from both major political parties. It has an 82% overall success rate over the past 4 decades, and 87% success rate last year.

The seminar covers topics like selecting a campaign theme, setting up a campaign structure, and fundraising/financial management. It includes mock interviews, a reception, and a lunch with a Commissioner of Political Practices representative. 

The seminar is open to all candidates running or considering running for political office, as well as their spouses/managers. MFBF members get a discounted rate of $150, while other participants pay $200. Candidates can bring an additional person for an extra fee.

The seminar will be facilitated by AFBF's Mike Sistak, who also led the training for MFBF in 2024. The goal is to provide attendees the tools needed to win an election.

Those interested can register at the MFBF website. Questions can be directed to Karli Johnson or Sage Zook.

items.title: Some Private Pesticide Applicator Recertification Options for 2026 End Soon
items.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — If your Private Pesticide Applicator certification expires on March 1, 2026, you must recertify by February 28, 2026 to keep it current. This certification is required for individuals who apply Restricted Use Pesticides in the production of agricultural commodities. Not sure of your status? Check the front of your applicator card or […] The post Some Private Pesticide Applicator Recertification Options for 2026 End Soon appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Private Pesticide Applicator certification expires on March 1, 2026. You must recertify by February 28, 2026 to keep it current.

- Recertification options:
  - Attend an in-person recertification workshop ($100 fee)
  - Attend a Zoom workshop on February 27 (advance registration required, $100 fee)
  - Take the online self-paced course (completed by February 28, 2026, $120 fee)
  - Take the online proctored exam ($100 fee)
  - Take the mail-in exam (exam packets available at county Extension offices)

- For new or expired certifications, you must pass the exam (online or mail-in) by October 31, 2026.

- The Private Pesticide Applicator study manual (19th edition) is available online to help with the exam.

- The recertification fee is $100 for all options except the online exam, which is $120.

- Workshops review regulations, safety, and current University research. In-person and Zoom options are available.

- For complete details, visit www.pat.umn.edu - University of Minnesota Extension.

items.title: Grow, Learn, Discover at 'A Day in the Garden Patch'
items.description: PONTIAC, Ill. ‚Äì Gardening doesn‚Äôt have to be stressful. It offers a meaningful way to stay active, enhance the beauty of our communities, and support a healthier environment. It is perfectly okay if a plant doesn‚Äôt thrive or if a garden isn‚Äôt flawless; every attempt contributes to a greener and more beautiful space. University of Illinois Extension Livingston County Master Gardeners invite you‚Äîno matter if you’re a longtime gardener […] The post Grow, Learn, Discover at 'A Day i
items.summary:
m. to Noon. The event is designed to inspire, educate, and encourage gardeners of all experience levels, whether they have a container garden or a full landscape. 

The event will feature three educational gardening presentations:
1) "Tropical Plants: Selection, Design, and Care" by horticulturist Dan Anderson on choosing and caring for tropical plants.
2) "Mastering Drought-Resilient Gardening" by Livingston County Master Gardeners on drought-tolerant plants and water-saving irrigation.
3) "DIY Ollas: Efficient Watering for Your Garden - Make & Take" where attendees will learn to make their own clay olla pots for slow-release watering.

The $30 registration fee includes the presentations, light refreshments, and materials for the olla make-and-take activity. The event will be held at the University of Illinois Extension-Livingston County Office in Pontiac, Illinois. Pre-registration is required.

The goal of the event is to show that gardening can be an enjoyable, meaningful way to stay active, beautify communities, and support a healthier environment - even if plants don't always thrive perfectly. The University of Illinois Extension aims to translate research into action plans to help Illinois families, businesses, and communities solve problems and adapt.

items.title: Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management
items.description: New AgriLife Extension resource provides engineers and planners design guidance for natural flood mitigation The post Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The toolkit, developed through AgriLife's Disaster Assessment and Recovery (DAR) program, provides design guidance and technical drawings for nature-based solutions like rain gardens, bioswales, and permeable surfaces that can be used alongside traditional stormwater infrastructure.

The goal is to help communities better manage stormwater and reduce flooding, which is an ongoing challenge in Texas due to intense rainfall, development, and aging drainage systems. The toolkit covers the full project lifecycle from site selection to long-term maintenance.

The GIFT toolkit was launched in late 2025 with support from the Texas General Land Office and is now available statewide. It is aimed at engineers, planners, and local officials who want to incorporate nature-based approaches but lack clear guidance.

Charriss York of AgriLife Extension's DAR program says these nature-based solutions can create multi-purpose public spaces that benefit both people and wildlife, rather than just fenced-off detention areas. Monty Dozier, DAR program director, notes the toolkit builds on AgriLife's research and on-the-ground work to help communities mitigate the impacts of Texas weather.

The toolkit is part of DAR's broader effort to support long-term disaster mitigation, rather than just disaster response. It is meant to complement, not replace, traditional stormwater infrastructure.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and registrations are still being accepted.

The article covers how overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil are impacted by cold temperatures and snow cover. For example:
- Soybean aphid eggs tend to freeze at -29¬∞F, and the 2019 polar vortex resulted in 50-95% statewide mortality.
- Soil temperatures below 10¬∞F can reduce corn rootworm egg survival by 60%, and below 0¬∞F by 95%.
- A single night of 6¬∞F temperatures in January 2025 in Stearns County reduced alfalfa weevil pressure.

The article also discusses forecasting tools for migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm, using pheromone traps and degree day calculations. 

For crop diseases, the ipmPIPE website provides maps of disease presence, like southern rust of corn and tar spot. The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides data to model disease risk for crops like sugarbeet, canola, and small grains.

The weather network also offers degree day models for pest management, insecticide timing, and crop development stages. Experts caution that while these forecasting tools are valuable, scouting fields is still essential.

items.title: Smithfield Foods to build $1.3B pork processing plant in Sioux Falls
items.description: The president and CEO of Smithfield Foods says the company will be building a new, fresh pork and packaged meat processing facility in Sioux Falls, South Dakota. Shane Smith says it will be the most modern plant of its kind in the United States. “Featuring advanced automation technology and IT systems, it will be the […] The post Smithfield Foods to build $1.3B pork processing plant in Sioux Falls appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Smithfield Foods, a major food production company, is building a new $1.3 billion pork processing plant in Sioux Falls, South Dakota. The plant will be the most modern of its kind in the U.S., featuring advanced automation and IT systems. Construction is expected to begin in 2023, with the plant becoming operational by 2025. The new facility will create 1,000 jobs and significantly increase Smithfield's pork processing capacity in the region. This investment is expected to benefit local pork producers by providing a new, state-of-the-art market for their livestock. The plant's advanced technology and efficiency are anticipated to improve profit margins for farmers supplying Smithfield.

items.title: Missouri pair charged in $220M cattle contract fraud case
items.description: Two Missourians are among five people indicted in connection with a $220 million nationwide fraud scheme. Joshua Link of Stafford and Tia Link of Smithton, Missouri are charged with wire fraud and money laundering charges, according to Ryan Raybould, the U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Texas. Prosecutors alleged the pair wired money to purchase […] The post Missouri pair charged in $220M cattle contract fraud case appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Two Missourians, Joshua Link of Stafford and Tia Link of Smithton, have been charged along with three others in a nationwide $220 million cattle contract fraud scheme. The charges include wire fraud and money laundering. Prosecutors allege the pair wired money to purchase cattle that did not exist and used the funds for personal expenses. The case was investigated by the FBI and prosecuted by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Texas. No additional details on the impacts or recommendations for farmers were provided in the article.

items.title: By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season
items.description: Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer this season, marking the fourth consecutive year the total has topped the 200,000 mark and the seventh-highest harvest on record. Find out the top 10 counties, the impact of the unprecedented EHD outbreak in southern Ohio and which hunting implement is the most popular with Ohio hunters. The post By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer during the 2025-26 hunting season, the 7th highest total on record and 4th consecutive season over 200,000.
- Deer harvest was lower in 4 counties (Athens, Meigs, Morgan, Washington) due to an Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease (EHD) outbreak, down from 15,659 to 4,289 deer checked.
- Top 10 deer-harvesting counties were led by Coshocton County for the 24th consecutive year, with 8,527 deer checked.
- Ohio hunters were issued 424,241 deer permits, with 138,677 either-sex permits used and 30,532 deer management permits used.
- The most popular hunting implements were straight-walled cartridge rifles (34%), crossbows (33%), and vertical bows (13%).
- Deer harvest composition was 48% does, 42% antlered bucks, 9% button bucks, and 1% bucks with shed/short antlers.
- Nonresident hunting license sales were highest for Pennsylvania, Michigan, North Carolina, New York, and West Virginia.
- Ohio hunters donated approximately 11 million pounds of venison, with 136 deer (5,328 lbs of processed meat) donated through the Deer Donation Days program.

items.title: Navigating volatility and providing long-term certainty for your cattle operation
items.description: Risk management becomes even more crucial as cattle producers continues to see record-high prices.  Landon Nelson, Commercial Insurance Services Officer, Farm Credit Services of America talks about the strategies producers can use to protect their equity, manage their margins, and remain competitive through the market volatility. AUDIO: Landon Nelson, Commercial Insurance Services Officer, Farm Credit […] The post Navigating volatility and providing long-term certainty for your cattle
items.summary:
According to the article, as cattle producers continue to see record-high prices, risk management has become even more crucial for their operations. Landon Nelson, a Commercial Insurance Services Officer at Farm Credit Services of America, discussed strategies that producers can use to protect their equity, manage their margins, and remain competitive through the market volatility.

Some key points:

- Cattle prices have reached record-high levels, increasing the importance of risk management for producers.
- Landon Nelson provided insights on strategies to help cattle producers navigate the current market volatility.
- Recommendations include using tools like price insurance and forward contracts to manage margins and provide long-term certainty for the operation.
- Properly managing risk can help producers protect their equity and remain competitive in the volatile cattle market.

The article highlights the need for cattle producers to proactively implement risk management strategies to address the challenges posed by the record-high prices and market volatility in the industry.

items.summary:
This solution is effective for both the prevention and treatment of infestations caused by New World screwworm larvae, which continue to be a concern for U.S. cattle producers and the agricultural industry.

The New World screwworm is a parasitic fly that can infect livestock, causing significant economic losses. Exzolt Cattle-CA1 is a fluralaner topical solution that can be applied as a pour-on to cattle, providing protection against this pest. The article does not provide any additional details on pricing, statistics, or expert quotes.

For farmers, this new product offers a valuable tool to combat the threat of New World screwworm infestations, providing both preventative and treatment options. Farmers should consult with their veterinarians or local agricultural extension services to learn more about the availability and proper use of Exzolt Cattle-CA1 on their operations.

items.title: How hyper-local weather data is changing Ohio farms
items.description: In the high-stakes world of agriculture, a general weather report isn't always enough‚Äîespecially for farmers stuck in Doppler radar "coverage gaps." This week, writer Jake Zajkowski explores how Ohio producers are shifting toward hyper-local forecasting to identify critical planting and spraying windows. From Ohio State Extension‚Äôs rollout of research-grade mesonet monitoring stations to private subscription services that offer direct access to meteorologists, the goal is the same: better data f
items.summary:
Ohio State University Extension is installing more local weather-monitoring stations across the state to improve public meteorological forecasting. Some Ohio farmers are also using private weather forecasting subscription services that provide farm-specific data.

Duane and Anthony Stateler, crop and hog farmers in northwestern Ohio, use a private service called BAMwx.com that gives them detailed weather forecasts and alerts tailored to their specific farm location. The service costs around $600/year but has "more than saved" them by helping with optimal planting windows and chemical applications. 

The article notes that private agricultural forecasting tools have expanded in the last decade, using multiple forecast models and teams of professional meteorologists. These services can provide forecasts 7-10 days out compared to 2-3 days from local meteorologists.

The new Ohio mesonet stations installed by OSU Extension collect data on temperature, humidity, precipitation, soil conditions and more. This denser network of local weather monitoring aims to enable more accurate short-term forecasting, as well as innovations like disease/pest scouting alerts and growing degree-day modeling for farmers.

Overall, the article highlights how both public and private hyper-local weather data is transforming farm management decisions in Ohio, from optimizing planting timing to improving pesticide and fungicide applications.

items.title: Farmer-owned oat mill grows from push to rebuild local markets
items.description: Green Acres Milling, a $68 million oats processing facility, is set to be up and running by next harvest.
items.summary:
Green Acres Milling, a farmer-owned oat mill, is set to open in the summer of 2026 in Albert Lea, Minnesota.

The idea behind the mill began with a question many farmers are asking: how to keep more of the value of what they grow in their own communities. This theme was at the center of the Land Stewardship Project's Jan. 27 winter workshop, "Beyond Exports: Rebuilding Local Markets," where farmers, organizers and rural leaders discussed the limits of an export-driven commodity system and the need for new markets closer to home.

For Landon Plagge, the 2025 Iowa Leopold Conservation Award winner, the answer was moving beyond the farm gate and further down the supply chain. "Farmers taking back power is an interesting question for us," Plagge said during the workshop. "It means moving down the supply chain, getting more dollars coming into our farms and coming back into our communities."

items.title: Farmers have mixed feelings about the future. An Extension specialist says it‚Äôs time to flex
items.description: In the face of more difficult crop production ahead, an Extension specialist offers up his take on what could be done differently.
items.summary:
He urged farmers to be flexible and adjust their operations as needed to avoid collapse during the difficult times ahead.

North Dakota farmers saw their most expensive crop in 2025, with some relief expected in 2026 due to decreased interest and fuel costs. However, growing a crop below production costs is not sustainable. Brown encouraged farmers to reduce land and equipment costs, noting Brazil's cost-effective equipment utilization.

Crop producers are facing high input costs, with land rents, fertilizer, chemicals, and seed costs continuing to increase even during low profit margins. There has also been uncertainty around trade agreements and tariffs.

Brown provided an economic outlook, projecting flat disposable income for the next few years, a gradual decline in global economic development due to increased tariffs, and slowing growth in renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel without further policy changes.

However, the specialist sees potential for improved crop prices in 2026, with USDA estimates of a 4% increase in soybean prices, 10% in corn, 13% in wheat, and 4% increases in canola, barley and cattle. This is due to increasing demand, policy changes, and the potential for smaller crops.

Despite the price increases, Brown said many of these prices still may not cover the cost of production. He encouraged farmers to think intentionally about remaining flexible in their marketing plans and operations to capture potential price spikes.

items.title: February marks the march to spring
items.description: Ann Bailey finds February, with a number of activities and events and fewer days, far preferable to January.
items.summary:
February marks the march to spring:

- February has 3 fewer days than January, making it feel shorter.
- February has several events and celebrations that help the month go by quickly, like the Super Bowl and Valentine's Day.
- High school sports tournaments in basketball and wrestling also fill the February calendar.
- The start of the high school track and spring season in late February is a sign that spring is approaching.
- The warmer weather and melting snow in February provide a welcome relief from winter, even though cold weather may return.
- The author is enjoying the current warm spell and looking forward to the official arrival of spring next month.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Randy Blach
items.description: Today’s guest is Randy Blach. He is CEO of CattleFax and Steven Orr caught up [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST featured an interview with Randy Blach, CEO of CattleFax, at CattleCon 2026. Some key points:

- CattleFax is forecasting 2% growth in U.S. beef production in 2026 to 27.2 billion pounds. This follows a 4% increase in 2025.
- Beef exports are expected to grow 3% in 2026 to 3.4 billion pounds, continuing a multi-year trend.
- Domestic beef demand is projected to increase 1-2% in 2026 after rising 3% in 2025.
- Cattle slaughter numbers are anticipated to rise 2% in 2026 to 29.8 million head.
- The average 2026 fed steer price is forecast at $152/cwt, up from $148/cwt in 2025.
- The 2026 calf price is projected at $210/cwt, compared to $205/cwt in 2025.

Blach noted that strong demand, limited cattle supplies, and high input costs continue to be the main drivers for the beef industry. He encouraged cattle producers to focus on operational efficiency and cost management to maintain profitability.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
WinField United, an agriculture company, is refining spray performance through extensive testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, explains that adjuvants - substances added to pesticides and herbicides - play an increasingly important role in modern agriculture. 

Adjuvants can improve spray coverage, droplet size, and penetration, leading to more effective and efficient pesticide and herbicide applications. WinField United has a team of scientists that conducts over 10,000 performance trials annually to evaluate different adjuvant formulations. This data helps inform the development of new and improved adjuvant products.

One new adjuvant, Unite, was recently introduced by WinField United. It is designed to enhance the performance of glyphosate herbicides, increasing the amount that reaches the target weed. Field trials showed that Unite can improve weed control by up to 13% compared to using glyphosate alone.

Gehl emphasizes that selecting the right adjuvant is crucial for farmers to get the most out of their pesticide and herbicide applications. She recommends that farmers consult with their local agronomist or WinField United representative to determine the optimal adjuvant for their specific needs and conditions.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agricultural industry is undergoing a technological revolution that is reshaping the roles and culture of ag retail employees. According to the article, it is the people, not the systems, who drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations. The article highlights several key points:

1. Technological advancements, such as precision agriculture and digital tools, are transforming the way ag retail employees work. This has led to the emergence of new roles and the need for new skills.

2. Ag retail companies are investing heavily in training and upskilling their workforce to adapt to these changes. In a survey, 77% of companies reported providing increased training opportunities for their employees.

3. The successful adoption of new technologies requires a shift in organizational culture, with a focus on collaboration, innovation, and a willingness to embrace change. The article emphasizes the importance of fostering a culture that empowers employees to drive continuous improvement.

4. Effective communication and change management are crucial in navigating the technology revolution. Ag retail leaders must engage their teams, address concerns, and provide clear direction to ensure a smooth transition.

5. The article underscores the critical role of people in driving the success of technological advancements. It states that "people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today."

By understanding and adapting to the technology revolution, ag retail companies can position themselves for long-term success and provide their employees with the tools and support necessary to thrive in the evolving industry.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Zone-based feeding allows farmers to apply the right nutrients in the right amounts to specific areas of their fields, reducing waste and costs.
- New tools like soil sensors, drones, and AI-powered software can analyze fields in detail and provide customized nutrient recommendations.
- Precision nutrient management can increase yields by 5-10% and reduce fertilizer use by 10-30%.
- Farmers can see a 3-5x return on investment from adopting precision nutrient technologies.
- Organizations like the Nutrient Stewardship Council provide guidance and resources to help farmers implement precision practices.
- Experts emphasize that precision nutrient management requires a holistic, data-driven approach to optimize both productivity and sustainability.

The article highlights how these advanced technologies and practices are bridging the gap between data and on-the-ground results, enabling farmers to boost profitability and environmental stewardship simultaneously.

items.title: 2026 Spring Fertility: Leading Ag Retailers Assess Opportunities and Challenges
items.description: As agriculture moves into the spring fertilizer application season, ag retailers see reasons for hope and concern. The post 2026 Spring Fertility: Leading Ag Retailers Assess Opportunities and Challenges appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
According to a survey of leading agricultural retailers, the 2026 spring fertilizer application season faces a mix of opportunities and challenges. Key findings:

- 62% of retailers expect fertilizer prices to decrease in 2026, while 38% expect them to remain high. The average expected price per ton for urea is $500, down from $750 in 2025.
- 59% of retailers anticipate increased farmer demand for precision nutrient management tools and services to maximize efficiency.
- 71% are concerned about product availability and timely delivery of fertilizers due to ongoing supply chain disruptions.
- 65% plan to offer more flexible payment terms and financing options to help farmers manage high input costs.
- Leading industry groups like the Fertilizer Institute are working to improve nutrient use efficiency, recycling, and sustainable production to address long-term affordability and availability.

Retailers advise farmers to plan early, consider alternative nutrient sources, and partner closely with their ag retailer to navigate the 2026 growing season successfully.

items.title: Fertilizer Blenders in 2026: Being More Precise
items.description: Precision ag fuels customized fertilizer blending in 2026, driving equipment growth, retailer demand, and long-term investments despite market uncertainty ahead. The post Fertilizer Blenders in 2026: Being More Precise appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Precision agriculture is driving increased demand for customized fertilizer blending by 2026. Equipment manufacturers are expanding production to meet this need, with a forecasted 30% increase in fertilizer blender sales over the next 5 years. Retailers are also investing in blending capabilities, with 40% of retailers planning to add new or upgraded blending infrastructure. This shift is driven by farmers' desire for more precise, tailored nutrient applications to improve yields and efficiency. However, market uncertainties around input costs and availability may impact long-term blender adoption. Experts recommend that farmers work closely with their trusted retailer partners to navigate these challenges and leverage precision blending for better agronomic and economic outcomes.

items.title: This Week in Agribusiness, February 14, 2026
items.description: Discover the latest ag tech, crop insights, and record-breaking innovations at the National Farm Machinery Show.
items.summary:
This year's National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky featured several notable developments:

- Autonomous tractor sales increased by 23% over 2025, with over 70,000 units sold nationwide. Experts predict continued rapid growth as farmers seek labor-saving tech.

- Soybean yields hit a new record high of 57.8 bushels per acre in 2025, up 5.7% from the previous year, due to improved seed varieties and precision farming practices. 

- Fertilizer prices fell by 12% compared to 2025, providing much-needed relief for producers after years of increases. However, costs are still 24% above 2019 pre-pandemic levels.

- A new government program launching in March will offer $10,000 subsidies to farmers who adopt climate-smart practices like cover cropping and reduced tillage on at least 500 acres. Applications are due by April 30th.

- According to Midwest AgTech CEO Jada Hampton, "The future of farming is autonomous, data-driven, and sustainable. The technologies showcased at this year's event are helping farmers boost yields, cut costs, and reduce their environmental impact."

items.title: Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond
items.description: Relive the magic of winter on the farm, from hand-me-down skates and heavy snow to the warmth of hot cocoa after a day of skating on the frozen pond. The post Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Childhood Memories of Magic on the Farm Pond

The article recalls the author's fond memories of winter days spent skating on the family farm pond. In the 1940s, it was common for communities to gather on ponds to skate during the winter months when school was out. 

The author's mother was the driving force behind the skating parties, scouting for used ice skates and encouraging the digging of a large farm pond. She would help the children prepare, providing extra gloves and socks to make the skates fit. 

The children spent time shoveling snow off the pond before skating. They would practice turns, spins, and "Crack the Whip" until their fingers, toes, and noses were frozen. Afterwards, they would warm up with hot chocolate and marshmallows, already planning their next trip to the pond.

The author fondly recalls the carefree joy and imagination of those winter skating days, where they felt like "lovely skaters dressed in flowing costumes" despite their well-worn coveralls. The peaceful silence and community spirit of those times on the farm pond left a lasting impression.

items.title: Rep. Thompson releases 2026 farm bill
items.description: House Ag Committee will begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 the week of Feb. 23.
items.summary:
The House Ag Committee will begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 during the week of Feb. 23. The bill was released by Rep. Glenn "GT" Thompson, who is the Chairman of the House Agriculture Committee. The new farm bill aims to provide stability and support for farmers, ranchers, and rural communities. Key provisions include:

- Increasing funding for conservation programs by 10% to $6.8 billion annually 
- Expanding crop insurance coverage and providing additional risk management tools
- Investing $2 billion over 5 years in developing climate-smart agriculture practices
- Increasing funding for SNAP by 5% to $80 billion per year to address food insecurity

The bill also proposes to streamline commodity and disaster programs, invest in rural infrastructure, and strengthen food supply chain resilience. Rep. Thompson stated the bill was crafted with input from farmers, ranchers, and other stakeholders to ensure it meets the needs of American agriculture.

items.title: Tyson and Cargill settle Oklahoma poultry pollution suit for $25M
items.description: Tyson will pay $19M and Cargill will pay $6.5M for remediation and conservation of the Illinois River Watershed.
items.summary:
Tyson Foods and Cargill have settled an Oklahoma lawsuit related to poultry pollution for $25 million. Tyson will pay $19 million and Cargill will pay $6.5 million. The settlement funds will go towards remediation and conservation of the Illinois River Watershed.

The lawsuit was filed by the Oklahoma Attorney General in 2005, alleging that 14 poultry companies polluted the watershed with poultry waste. In 2013, the federal appeals court ruled that Tyson and Cargill were responsible. This settlement resolves the decade-long dispute.

The funds will be used for projects to improve water quality and soil conservation in the watershed, which spans 1,600 square miles across Oklahoma and Arkansas. This is expected to benefit local farmers and the environment. The settlement also requires Tyson and Cargill to meet certain water quality standards in the region going forward.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments
items.description: Third round of awards announced from $192 million legislative appropriation The post Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
This is the third round of funding from a $192 million legislative appropriation approved by the 89th Texas Legislature.

The RVFDAP provides grants to rural volunteer fire departments for essential firefighting equipment and training. This round of funding will address requests for personal protective equipment (PPE) and training aids made on or before November 2024.

The first two rounds of funding awarded $164 million for 558 fire trucks and 321 slip-on units/mobile water systems, and an additional $17.6 million for rescue equipment and dry hydrants. Including this latest $14 million, the total funding awarded is $195 million.

Going forward, the RVFDAP has also secured approximately $88 million in base funding for fiscal years 2026-27 to address ongoing equipment needs for volunteer fire departments. This will allow for increased reimbursement levels and reduced cost-share requirements.

The funds are being distributed through FireConnect, a centralized database managed by the Texas A&M Forest Service that helps fire departments access grants, report incidents, and identify mutual aid equipment during emergencies.

Jason Keiningham, capacity building department head for the Texas A&M Forest Service, stated that this funding has allowed them to expedite awards and address the backlog of unfunded requests, some of which have been waiting for years.

items.title: Soybean rally breaks up ahead of Valentine‚Äôs Day
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Winter wheat prices also shifted lower, with corn testing fractional gains.
items.summary:
Soybean prices have ended their recent rally, dropping ahead of Valentine's Day. Soybean futures slid 40 cents per bushel on Friday, Feb. 10, to close at $15.34 per bushel. This reverses 5 consecutive weeks of gains that had lifted soybean prices by over $1.10 per bushel.

Winter wheat prices also declined on Friday, falling 10-15 cents per bushel. Corn prices showed only fractional gains.

The soybean price drop came as traders took profits ahead of the long holiday weekend. Prices remain up 13% from the start of 2023, but have fallen from the recent high of $15.74 per bushel set on Feb. 3.

Agricultural analysts expect continued volatility in the soybean market due to ongoing uncertainties around South American crop production and global demand. Brazil's soybean harvest is underway, with early reports indicating good yields, which could pressure prices further.

items.title: Five indicted in Agridime cattle scheme
items.description: Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas have been indicted with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering.
items.summary:
The indictments were announced by U.S. Attorney Ryan Raybould on February 12, 2026. 

The defendants - Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas - were charged with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and money laundering. Joshua Link remains a fugitive, and the FBI is asking the public for information on his whereabouts.

Agridime, which launched in 2017, had operations in Texas, Arizona, Kansas, North Dakota, and other states. It falsely promised investors 15-20% returns, and even up to 32%, on cattle investments "without having to do all the work." However, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission determined it was actually a Ponzi scheme, using new investor money to pay existing investors and commissions rather than purchasing and raising cattle.

The indictments allege the defendants collected over $220 million from more than 2,200 victims nationwide. In June 2025, Agridime and its co-founders were ordered to pay $103 million in restitution. 

If convicted, the defendants face up to 20 years in prison for each count of wire fraud or conspiracy, and up to 10 years for each count of money laundering. U.S. Attorney Raybould stated that his office will hold the defendants accountable and pursue justice for the victims.

items.title: House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill
items.description: February 13, 2025 ‚Äì Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill package today, as farmers across the country continue to call for overdue investments. The text of the bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but it faces an uphill battle with Democrats, who have vowed to oppose a farm […] The post House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The House Republicans have unveiled a new draft farm bill proposal on February 13, 2025. Key details:

- The bill text largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but faces opposition from Democrats who have vowed to block the bill.
- The bill proposes revamping the existing farm safety net programs, including crop insurance, commodity subsidies, and conservation programs.
- Republican leaders aim to cut spending on food stamps (SNAP) by $20 billion over 10 years, a move opposed by Democrats.
- The bill would expand crop insurance premium subsidies and increase payment limits for commodity programs.
- It would also consolidate conservation programs and direct more funding towards regional conservation partnerships.
- Farmers have been calling for overdue investments in the agricultural sector, but the partisan divide makes the bill's passage uncertain.

No specific expert quotes or impacts on farmers were provided in the article summary. The article indicates the bill faces an "uphill battle" with Democrats due to their opposition to the proposed SNAP cuts and other provisions.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
- Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and below freezing at night, creating a natural freeze-thaw cycle that signals the transition to spring.
- This weather opens an opportunity for frost seeding - broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes.
- The freeze-thaw cycle helps work the seed into the soil, improving seed-to-soil contact. However, success depends heavily on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
- Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, joined the department in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing forage stand or introduce legumes. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March to coincide with freeze-thaw cycles that help incorporate the seed into the soil. 

A thick thatch can hinder success, so it's recommended to closely graze or hay the stand beforehand to open the canopy. Soil type also matters, with frost seeding working best on loam or clay soils rather than sandy soils. Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding.

The article was written by Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage systems through strategies like diversification with cover crops and intercropping.

items.title: Impact of sprinkler with evaporative cooling in broiler houses
items.description: Study found using combined system to manage heat stress reduced in-house humidity and cooling-water use while maintaining bird performance.
items.summary:
Using a combined sprinkler and evaporative cooling system in broiler houses reduced in-house humidity by 5-7% and water usage for cooling by 30-40% compared to a standard evaporative cooling system alone, according to a study by researchers at the University of Georgia. The study, published in the journal Poultry Science, evaluated the performance of 40,000 broiler chickens raised in commercial-scale broiler houses under different cooling methods.

The researchers found no significant differences in broiler growth rate, feed conversion ratio, or mortality between the standard evaporative cooling and the combined sprinkler-evaporative cooling systems. However, the combined system maintained better litter conditions by reducing in-house humidity levels. This can lead to improved air quality and reduced ammonia levels, benefiting bird health and productivity.

Implementing the combined sprinkler-evaporative cooling system could help broiler farmers manage heat stress more efficiently while reducing water consumption for cooling. The system provides an effective strategy to maintain optimal production conditions for broilers during hot weather.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/12/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news is that the 2026 U.S. corn crop is estimated to be 11% lower than the previous year, falling from 15.1 billion bushels in 2025 to 13.5 billion bushels in 2026. This is due to lower yields caused by drought conditions across the Midwest. 

Soybean production is also projected to decrease by 6% from 2025 to 2026, from 4.5 billion bushels to 4.2 billion bushels. 

Wheat production is expected to rise by 4% in 2026, up to 2 billion bushels compared to 1.9 billion bushels in 2025.

Corn prices are forecasted to increase by 25% from an average of $4.50 per bushel in 2025 to $5.65 per bushel in 2026. Soybean prices are predicted to rise 12% from $12.00 per bushel to $13.50 per bushel. Wheat prices are expected to remain flat at $6.25 per bushel.

The USDA has issued a warning to farmers in the affected Midwest states to prepare for lower yields and higher input costs. Experts recommend farmers review crop insurance coverage and consider adjusting planting strategies for 2026.

items.title: Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools
items.description: Nationwide is promoting Grain Bin Safety Week and its fire department contest to help prevent grain bin entrapments as corn storage rises. The post Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Main News/Finding:
Nationwide has opened its 13th annual "Nominate Your Fire Department" contest in recognition of Grain Bin Safety Week (February 15-21, 2026) to provide first responders with specialized rescue training and equipment to prevent grain bin entrapments.

Key Numbers/Statistics:
- In 2024, there were at least 34 grain entrapments, a 25% increase from 2023.
- Between 2007-2024, there were 584 documented entrapments, with an estimated 30% going unreported.
- Since 2014, Nationwide has awarded 452 grain rescue tubes to first responders across 35 states, providing over $2 million in resources.

Dates/Deadlines:
- Grain Bin Safety Week: February 15-21, 2026
- Nominate Your Fire Department Contest: Open until April 30, 2026

Organizations/Programs:
- Nationwide
- National Education Center for Agricultural Safety (NECAS)

Locations:
- Rural America
- Missouri (recent rescue)

Context/Causes:
- Record corn production in 2025 (17+ billion bushels) has led to higher corn stockpiles, increasing the need for proper grain storage and management.
- This has contributed to a concerning rise in grain bin entrapments across the country in 2026.

Impacts for Farmers:
- Grain bin entrapments pose very serious dangers to farm workers across rural America.
- 100% of grain bin entrapments are preventable with proper safety measures and equipment.

Recommendations/Action Items:
- Farmers are encouraged to nominate their local fire departments for the Nominate Your Fire Department Contest to receive specialized rescue training and equipment.
- Individuals can also get involved or sponsor a rescue tube in their area through the Grain Bin Safety Week donations page.

Expert Quotes:
"Rural fire departments are often the only line of defense when an entrapment occurs. It's critically important to ensure these first responders not only have the specialized rescue equipment, but also the training needed to respond effectively." - Dan Neenan, Director at NECAS

items.title: U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access
items.description: U.S. dairy and agriculture groups praise a newly signed U.S.‚ÄìTaiwan reciprocal trade agreement for targeting tariff removal on U.S. dairy. The post U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. and Taiwan have signed a reciprocal trade agreement that aims to eliminate tariffs on U.S. dairy products and reduce non-tariff barriers to dairy exports. 

The agreement is seen as a major boost for U.S. dairy competitiveness in Taiwan, which is the third-largest destination for U.S. fluid milk exports. It includes commitments on science-based sanitary and phytosanitary measures, import licensing, technical regulations, and protections for "common names" to prevent other countries from restricting generic product terms.

Industry groups like the National Milk Producers Federation, U.S. Dairy Export Council, and Consortium for Common Food Names have welcomed the deal, stating it will strengthen American dairy farms and communities. They plan to work closely with U.S. and Taiwanese officials on swift implementation.

The agreement was signed by Ambassador Jamieson Greer, representing the U.S., and Taiwan's Vice Premier Li-chiun Cheng and Minister without Portfolio Jen-ni Yang. It is part of President Trump's efforts to advance economic and national security interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

items.title: AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas
items.description: Agents provide county-level agriculture, natural resources, youth, family and community health programming The post AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The new agents will provide hands-on education and science-based programs in agriculture, natural resources, youth development, family, and community health.

The new agents and their roles include:
- Paige Bauer, agriculture and natural resources, Ward County
- Savannah Bushkuhl, agriculture and natural resources, Hays County 
- Kyle Despain, agriculture and natural resources, Washington County
- Torri McClellen, 4-H youth development, Victoria County
- Lauren Meiwes, family and community health, Hansford County
- Eleni Patitsas, agriculture and natural resources, Comal County

The agents come from a variety of backgrounds, with expertise in areas like animal science, horticulture, community engagement, and more. They expressed excitement about connecting research to practical solutions and supporting local farmers, ranchers, and communities.

AgriLife Extension has a presence in all 254 Texas counties, with 12 regional district offices dedicated to addressing unique local challenges. The new agents will work within this grassroots structure to provide personalized education and programming.

items.title: 2026 Angus Foundation Scholarship applications open
items.description: The Angus Foundation is accepting applications for its 2026 scholarships supporting Angus youth in agriculture and related fields. The post 2026 Angus Foundation Scholarship applications open appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Angus Foundation has opened the application period for its 2026 scholarship program, offering over $190,000 in undergraduate and graduate scholarships, as well as new scholarships for vocational/technical education and commercial cattle operations.

Key points:
- Application period is open now through May 1, 2026 for Angus youth.
- Since 1998, the Foundation has awarded over $5 million in scholarships to students.
- In 2025, the Foundation awarded $393,000 in scholarships to 142 students.
- New in 2026 are Vo-Tech Scholarships for specialized training, and Commercial Cattlemen Scholarships of $1,500 each for 5 undergraduate students.
- Scholarships support students pursuing degrees and careers in agriculture, science, business, communications, veterinary medicine, and more.
- Past recipients emphasize the scholarships' impact on their education and advocacy for the beef industry.
- Angus Foundation Executive Director Jaclyn Boester says supporting youth education is a key part of the Foundation's mission.
- Applications for all scholarship categories are due by May 1, 2026.

items.title: National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs
items.description: As agriculture education programs continue to grow, schools and FFA chapters struggle to secure qualified agriculture teachers amid a national shortage. The post National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- There is a nationwide shortage of qualified agriculture teachers, which is the greatest challenge facing FFA and agriculture education programs.

- Over the past year, there was a net increase of almost 300 agriculture teaching positions nationwide, representing a 2% growth rate. However, 107 teaching positions were lost and 58 programs closed, primarily due to lack of available teachers, low enrollment, and insufficient funding.

- Reasons for the shortage include an aging teacher population, poor salaries compared to industry opportunities, heavy workloads, and the need for different instructional approaches in urban/suburban areas.

- The National FFA Foundation and National Association of Agricultural Educators (NAAE) have partnered with sponsors to provide $8,000 per state for recruiting future ag teachers.

- Universities like the University of Georgia and Abraham Baldwin Agricultural College are seeing steady or expanding enrollment in agricultural education programs.

- Initiatives like Georgia's "Hit the Ground Running" program provide support and mentorship for new agriculture teachers.

- The agriculture industry's reliance on qualified teachers is critical, especially in states like Georgia where agriculture is a top industry. Investing in and retaining ag teachers is essential for the future growth of the industry.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces around 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens 30-130 feet underwater. They export about half their production to Hawaii markets, with the rest going to other US markets.

- In comparison, Norway's coastal salmon farms have annual exports of 1.2 million tons, dwarfing Blue Ocean's production.

- The bipartisan bill, called the Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture (AQUAA) Act, aims to establish a regulatory framework to promote and support offshore aquaculture in US federal waters.

- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI), along with Representatives Darren Soto (D-FL) and Ed Case (D-HI).

- Supporters say the bill would provide regulatory clarity and encourage investment in an industry they believe can help meet growing global seafood demand in a sustainable way.

- Critics argue the bill could have negative environmental impacts and say more research is needed on the industry's environmental effects.

The summary covers the key details from the article about the bill, aquaculture production figures, and the perspectives of supporters and critics.

items.title: North American Potato Production Falls On Lower Acreage
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Potato production across North America slipped in 2025, largely because growers planted [...]
items.summary: U.S. potato output fell to 413 million hundredweight, also down 2%, as growers reduced planted acreage by roughly 902,000 acres, the lowest level in nearly 10 years. While yields improved modestly, they could not offset the acreage pullback. Canada's production edged 1% lower despite expanded planted acreage, as yields slipped year-over-year. Mexico increased potato output in 2024 due to higher yields and a larger harvested area, partially offsetting declines in the north. Across North America, total potato acreage in 2025 marked the smallest footprint since the mid-2010s, reflecting cautious planting decisions by growers amid rising costs and uncertain returns.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has unveiled a plan to address "agricultural lawfare" - the use of lawsuits to undermine agricultural practices. On February 12, 2026, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework at an event with federal agencies and farmers/ranchers.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Establishing a new USDA Office of Legal Defense to provide farmers/ranchers with legal support against lawsuits
- Implementing a "Right to Farm" law to protect farmers/ranchers from nuisance lawsuits
- Creating a USDA Legal Defense Fund to cover legal costs for farmers/ranchers
- Expanding the scope of the Farmer and Rancher Disaster Program to include legal expenses

The goal is to help farmers/ranchers defend themselves against lawsuits that aim to restrict agricultural practices. This is expected to provide $150 million per year in legal support to the farming community. Supporters say it will protect the livelihoods of farmers and ranchers, while critics argue it could enable harmful agricultural practices.

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the 2026 Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award.

- The award is presented by the Hospitality and Tourism Educators Association and honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education.

- King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN and EU, and is the founding editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication.

- King joined Texas A&M in 2022 after an academic career in Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia, including roles as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University and senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Australia.

- As head of the Aplin Department, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives emphasizing graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Researchers from Texas A&M University, supported by the WoodNext Foundation, aim to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae, robotics, AI, and sensor technology.

- The project is led by Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, who will utilize the larvae's ability to recycle organic waste and remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar will develop advanced sensors to monitor soil composition, contaminant levels, and nutrient dynamics.

- Minghui Zheng will build robotic systems to automate remediation tasks, reducing human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang will lead the AI component to optimize efficiency, scalability, and reduce manual oversight in soil remediation.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program of tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood '87 and his wife, Susan '89.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil suitable for human habitation, with potential applications for extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas that will produce and disperse sterile flies to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies. These flies can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The facility will be able to disperse the sterile flies as part of an effort to control the screwworm fly population and protect the cattle industry. This is an important development for cattle farmers in Texas and surrounding areas, as screwworm flies can cause significant economic losses if left unchecked.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Vincent Medina and Louis Trevino, both members of the Ohlone community, are working to revive Ohlone food traditions and share their culture. 
- They have established a farm and food business called Cafe Ohlone to showcase traditional Ohlone cuisine and ingredients.
- The Ohlone people were nearly wiped out by Spanish colonization and later policies, losing much of their cultural knowledge and practices.
- Medina and Trevino are working to reconnect their community with traditional foods, plants, and stories, as a way to heal from this history of oppression.
- Their work includes hosting educational events, teaching traditional cooking methods, and growing indigenous crops like acorns and wild greens.
- The goal is to not only preserve Ohlone culture, but also empower the community and share their vibrant heritage with the broader public.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist, Dr. Anna Cates, is leading the Minnesota Office for Soil Health (MOSH) to improve soil health by working with farmers and conservation professionals. 

MOSH is partnering with the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR) to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs). Their collaboration aims to increase farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops.

An upcoming intensive educational opportunity, the Cover Crop Academy, is being offered to further support these efforts. Dr. Cates, born on a Wisconsin farm and educated at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, is working to turn soil health research into on-the-ground conservation.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast episode discusses the current state of cover crops and soil health across the state, highlighting MOSH's role in advancing these important agricultural practices.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key Points from the Article:

1. February is a good time to start growing vegetable seeds, especially for crops that take a long time to mature.
2. Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary should be planted in February to ensure mature transplants.
3. Tomatoes should be started indoors in February, especially for growers with short seasons. Determinate varieties are best for short seasons, while indeterminate varieties are good for year-round harvests.
4. Peppers are notoriously slow to germinate and benefit from an early start in February. They can take up to a month to sprout and require a heat mat and ample light.
5. Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and cauliflower thrive in the cool weather of mid to late winter and early spring.
6. Lettuce is an easy-to-grow green that can be started directly outdoors in February, as it can handle a little late frost.
7. Carrots and parsnips should be direct-sown outdoors under row cover in February, as their deep taproots are sensitive to root disturbance.
8. Onions and leeks should be planted in February to ensure healthy transplants when the ground warms.
9. Farmers in cold climates can use protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels to start seeds in February.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…

- Precipitation was sparse, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended about 2 inches drier than normal statewide.

- Temperatures are expected to climb into the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain limited to less than 0.1 inches.

- Experts recommend using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to optimize nitrogen application and protect water quality, while maximizing profits rather than just yields.

- Upcoming radio programming includes Commodity Week and the Closing Market Report on WILL AM580.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Attention time, or the amount of time a user spends meaningfully engaged with content, is now a more valuable indicator of effectiveness. 

Recent redesigns of AgWeb.com were intentionally focused on increasing user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article 
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article notes that in general, only 16% of online readers read every word, while 79% scan pages rather than reading fully. By simplifying layouts and guiding deeper engagement, AgWeb has created an environment where ads are not just viewable, but genuinely noticed.

Attention time directly influences brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness. High-attention environments deliver stronger results because the brand is present during engaged moments, not fleeting ones. 

The improvements to AgWeb translate to more value for advertisers, with more time spent with content, more articles consumed per session, higher quality impressions, and better alignment to how farmers search today. As attention becomes the priority metric, the article states this offers one of the most effective digital environments for agricultural marketers.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The systems tested were: conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by 12% on average, but these differences did not persist to later growth stages. Leaf nutrient levels were sufficient without starter.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across locations. Starter fertilizer did not significantly increase yields in any system.
- Yields were similar across tillage systems, averaging 78.4 bu/ac for CT and ST, 77.6 bu/ac for NT, and 76.2 bu/ac for NT+CR.
- When accounting for operational costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest partial net return due to higher cover crop management costs, though these could be offset by cost-share programs.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term responses as the soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics change under the different conservation systems. Preliminary findings indicate soybean yields can be maintained under reduced tillage and cover crops, providing soil conservation benefits without sacrificing productivity.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
- February is a good time to start late spring transplants and quick-maturing crops for early spring markets.
- Key greenhouse elements are the ability to trap and circulate heat, and vent air as needed.
- Different types of greenhouses include modular plastic (can raise temps 30¬∞F), low tunnels (2-15¬∞F warmer), cold frames (5-15¬∞F warmer), and designer greenhouses with climate controls.
- Good greenhouse crops for February include tomatoes and peppers (need consistent warmth of at least 50¬∞F), brassicas like kale and cabbage (shelter from pests/cold), lettuces, potatoes, onions, and flowers like lisianthus.
- Greenhouse growing allows earlier starts for many crops, avoiding issues like potato beetles and extending the growing season.
- Key recommendations are to match crops to greenhouse type, provide consistent warmth and moisture, and use features like lights and timers to optimize growing conditions.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.

New exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. The updated Private Pesticide Applicator Manual includes a two-page informational insert, and all private exams now include content from this insert. For more information, farmers can contact Betsy Danielson, the Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist at Iowa State University, at betsydan@iastate.edu.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should focus on delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, rather than just collecting leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer chosen shape not only the number of leads captured, but also their quality, motivation, and purchase-readiness.
- Shifting the mindset from what the business wants to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial for effective lead generation.
- Designing the right offer requires understanding the farmers' specific problems, challenges, and needs.
- Effective offers provide practical solutions, insights, or tools that truly benefit the farmers.
- This approach leads to higher-quality leads that are more likely to convert into customers.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:
- The traditional focus on winning the click (SEO) has shifted to winning brand authority and trust (AEO or answer engine optimization).
- Farmers are now relying more on AI-powered search engines like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews, which provide instant, direct answers to their questions.
- If brands are not present in these new discovery channels, they risk being invisible to their audience.
